title: Induction Cooking's Efficiency Advantage
description: A short lesson to help you apply Induction Cooking's Efficiency Advantage.

hook.text: An induction stove boils water in half the time of gas. It's 90% efficient; gas is just 40%â€”the rest heats your kitchen.

buildup.text: Induction uses electromagnetic fields to heat the pan directly. The cooktop stays coolâ€”only the cookware gets hot.

discovery.text: No combustion means no indoor pollution. Gas stoves emit nitrogen dioxide, benzene, and methane even with burners off.

twist.text: Stanford found gas stoves leak methane nonstop. Annual US stove leakage equals the COâ‚‚ output of 500,000 cars.

climax.text: Pro chefs once resisted induction, but top restaurants now prefer it for precise control and instant response.

punchline.text: The coolest cooking surface is also the hottest technology.

quiz.question: Why is induction cooking more energy-efficient than gas?
options: It heats the pan directly via electromagnetic fields, wasting almost no energy
It uses less electricity by cycling power on and off rapidly
The ceramic surface insulates heat, preventing loss to the air
